newsitem.title: ITALY: Gemina to hive off industrial interests.
newsitem.headline: Gemina to hive off industrial interests.

text.p: Italian industrial and financial holding company Gemina said on Friday it is to hive off its industrial interests into a new company called Holding di Partecipazioni Industriali HPI Spa.
The company said in a statement that all existing Gemina shareholders would receive nine shares in the new company HPI for every 10 Gemina shares held.
Following the hiving off, Gemina's net equity would fall to 230 billion lire from 2.305 trillion. HPI would have net equity of 2.075 trillion lire.
Gemina said its direct and indirect holdings in the following companies would be hived off into HPI:
Gemina Participations, RCS Editori, Fila, GFT, Cartiere Burgo, Pirelli & C, SMI, Banca Commerciale Italiana, Credito Italiano, Compagnie Monegasque de Banque and Istituto Europeo di Oncologia.
HPI would have reserves of 731 billion lire and liquid assets of 964 billion lire at the consolidated level.
Paid up company capital would total 1.343 trillion lire, divided into 2,573.87 mln ordinary shares and 112.883 million savings shares.
Gemina said a stock exchange listing would be sought for the new HPI shares but did not say when the split off would come into effect.
The company said the decision to hive off industrial assets into HPI was a "strategic choice of considerable importance" which would allow industrial and financial assets to be managed separately.
Gemina would manage a portfolio made up of Gemina Immobiliare, Gemina Capital Markets, Gemina Europe Bank, Banca di Credito e Commercio as well as other minority stakes including Fineurop Group.
The statement said newspaper and publishing group RCS, which disclosed heavy losses last year, showed continuing signs of improvement at the operating level.
The GFT textiles group was expected to show a further improvement in net results for the full year while sportswear group Fila was continuing to show rapid sales and profits growth.
